, Chairman and Managing Director of Reliance Industries Limited (RIL), has been ranked 32nd in the Forbes list of World’s Most Powerful People.
The list is topped by Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Ambani was ranked 40th last year.
He is followed by Microsoft founder Bill Gates at 33rd position, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg at 35th position and Google co-founder Larry Page at 36th position.
Other Indians on the list include Tata Group chairman Cyrus Mistry (71st), Infosys co-founder N R Narayana Murthy (89th) and Wipro chairman Azim Premji (95th).

, 1931-2014
Massimo Vignelli, the Italian-born designer who created some of the most recognizable corporate identities in American history, died on May 27 at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.
Mr. Vignelli’s work included the interiors and signage for New York City subway stations, the Bloomingdale’s department store logo, the Ford Motor Company logo and the United States Postal Service’s “Rainbow” stamp series.
He also designed the interior of the American Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport, which opened in 1962 and is still used today.
“His designs were so simple that they seemed obvious,” said Steven Heller, a graphic design historian and author of several books about Mr. Vignelli. “But he had an incredible eye for detail.”
Mr. Vignelli was born in Milan in 1931 and moved to the United States with his family when he was 11. He studied

, Queen: The Ultimate Illustrated History of the Crown Kings of Rock
Freddie Mercury, Queen: The Ultimate Illustrated History of the Crown Kings of Rock by Mark Blake
English | 2016 | ISBN: 178598043X | 256 Pages | EPUB | 1.1 MB
The definitive illustrated history of one of the most iconic bands in rock history - Queen.
Queen are one of the biggest and best-loved bands in the world. Their music has been a constant presence on radio and TV for decades, and their songs have become part of our collective consciousness. They have sold over 300 million records worldwide, making them one of the best-selling artists of all time.
This book tells the story of Queen's rise to fame, from their formation in London in 1970 through to their legendary performance at Live Aid in 1985. It features exclusive interviews with Brian May, Roger Taylor

, Plato and Aristotle are the three most important philosophers in Western philosophy. They were all Greek philosophers who lived between 500 BC and 300 AD.
Socrates was a philosopher from Athens, Greece. He is known for his method of questioning people to find out what they know and do not know. This method is called the Socratic Method. He believed that people should be honest with themselves and others. He also believed that people should live according to their own beliefs.
Plato was a student of Socrates. He wrote many books about philosophy. One of his most famous works is The Republic. In this book, he describes an ideal society. He believes that people should live in harmony with each other and with nature.
Aristotle was another student of Socrates. He wrote many books about philosophy. His most famous work is The Nicomachean Ethics. In this book, he discusses how people should live. He believes that people should live according to their own nature.

, Holocaust survivor and Nobel Peace Prize winner, dies at 87
Elie Wiesel, the Romanian-born Jewish writer and Holocaust survivor who won a Nobel Peace Prize for his eloquent pleas on behalf of the victims of genocide and became the world's leading spokesman on the Holocaust, died Saturday at age 87.
Wiesel was a teenager when he was sent to Auschwitz in 1944. He lost his mother and younger sister there, and later endured slave labor camps in Germany before being liberated by U.S. troops in 1945.
He went on to become one of the world's most prominent writers and thinkers, writing more than 50 books, including "Night," an account of his experiences in the death camps that has been translated into dozens of languages. The book was awarded the Prix Goncourt, France's top literary prize, in 1958.

' Widow Reveals She Was 'Shocked' By His Suicide
Robin Williams' widow, Susan Schneider, has revealed that she was "shocked" by the actor's suicide.
The 61-year-old comedian and actor took his own life in August last year at the age of 63, and his wife has now opened up about how she felt when she found out he had died.
Speaking to People magazine, she said: "I was shocked. I was devastated. I was heartbroken. I was angry. I was all those things."
She added: "It was a very difficult time for me. It was a very difficult time for my children. We were all just trying to figure it out."
Williams' death came as a huge shock to fans around the world, with many believing he would never take his own life.
His wife also revealed that she is still struggling to come to terms with her husband's passing, but she is doing

, the Nobel Prize-winning economist and philosopher, has been a leading voice in the worldwide movement for democracy. In this book he argues that democracy is not just a political system but also an ethical ideal, and that it requires us to think about what kind of people we are.
Sen begins by examining the meaning of democracy as a form of government, and then turns to its meaning as an ideal. He shows how democracy can be seen as a way of life, one that involves both individual freedom and social responsibility. The book explores the relationship between democracy and equality, and discusses the ways in which democratic societies should respond to issues such as poverty, discrimination, and terrorism. It concludes with a discussion of the role of democracy in the twenty-first century, and the challenges it faces from religious fundamentalism, economic globalization, and environmental degradation.
This new edition includes a substantial new preface by the author, in which he reflects on the state of democracy today.

, founder of Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts, has died at the age of 87.
Sharp founded Four Seasons in 1961 with a single hotel in Toronto. The company now operates more than 100 hotels and resorts around the world.
In a statement, the company said: “Isadore Sharp was an extraordinary visionary who built Four Seasons into one of the most respected luxury hospitality brands in the world.
“His legacy will live on through his family, our employees and the millions of guests who have enjoyed the unparalleled service that is the hallmark of Four Seasons.”

, the first woman to receive a medical degree in the United States, was born on February 3, 1821, in Bristol, England. She immigrated to the United States with her family at age 14 and settled in New York City. After graduating from Geneva Medical College in upstate New York in 1849, she opened an office in New York City as a physician for women. In 1857, she founded the Woman's Medical College of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children.
Blackwell married Dr. John H. Hobhouse in 1846. They had one child, who died in infancy.

, the Japanese-Peruvian chef who has made a name for himself with his fusion cuisine, is opening a new restaurant in New York City.
The 10th location of the Nobu brand will be located at 250 Park Avenue South and will open in early 2013. The space was previously occupied by the now-closed Aureole.
Matsuhisa's restaurants are known for their sushi and sashimi dishes as well as their signature black cod dish.

, Google's co-founder and CEO, has announced that the company is working on a new project called Calico. The goal of this project is to "focus on health and well being."
The company says it will be "an independent company" with its own board of directors. It will be led by Arthur Levinson, former CEO of Genentech and current chairman of Apple's board.
Google has been making moves in the health space for some time now. In 2013, the company acquired Lift Labs, which makes a smartwatch for people who are blind or have low vision. Last year, Google also bought a startup called DeepMind Technologies, which specializes in artificial intelligence.

, a Native American activist and author, will speak at 7 p.m. Thursday in the University Union Ballroom on the campus of Northern Arizona University.
LaDuke is an internationally renowned speaker on issues related to sustainable development, renewable energy, food systems, native rights and environmental justice. She has been named one of Time magazine’s “50 Heroes for the Planet” and was awarded the prestigious Right Livelihood Award in 2010.
The event is sponsored by NAU’s College of Social and Behavioral Sciences and the Center for Native American Studies.

’s Lady Bird is a film about the relationship between a mother and daughter, but it’s also a film about growing up. It’s a coming-of-age story that doesn’t follow the typical formula of a teenager trying to find themselves in high school. Instead, it follows Christine “Lady Bird” McPherson (Saoirse Ronan) as she tries to figure out who she wants to be after graduation.
The film opens with Lady Bird (as she prefers to be called) at her Catholic high school, where she has just been accepted into an East Coast college. The two have a strained relationship, and Marion is worried that Lady Bird will never come back home.

, the 2013 U.S. Amateur champion and a member of Japan's victorious Presidents Cup team in October, has withdrawn from next week's WGC-HSBC Champions event in Shanghai because of an injury to his left wrist.
Matsuyama was scheduled to play in the $7 million tournament at Sheshan International Golf Club, which begins Thursday. He is ranked No. 4 in the world and won the Bridgestone Invitational last month for his second career victory on the PGA Tour.
The Japanese star said he injured his wrist during practice last week in Japan. He will be replaced by American Kevin Na, who is currently No. 58 in the world rankings.

, Megan Rapinoe and the U.S. women's soccer team are suing the U.S. Soccer Federation for gender discrimination.
The lawsuit was filed in California on Wednesday by the players' union and 28 members of the national team. The suit alleges that the USSF pays female players less than their male counterparts, even though they generate more revenue for the federation.
"Despite the fact that the United States Women's National Team is the most successful team in the history of American sports, the USSF has never paid the WNT a salary commensurate with the men's national team," the lawsuit states. "Instead, the USSF pays the WNT substantially less than the men's national team."
The lawsuit also claims that the USSF has failed to promote equal pay between the men's and women's teams. It says the federation has not provided equal support services, such as training facilities and travel expenses.

was born into slavery in 1797. She escaped with her infant daughter to freedom in 1826, and became a leading abolitionist speaker. In this speech she tells the story of her life as a slave and a woman, and calls on women to stand up for their rights.
Sojourner Truth (c. 1797-1883) was an African American abolitionist and women's rights activist. Born Isabella Baumfree, she was sold several times as a child and eventually escaped from slavery with her infant daughter. She changed her name to Sojourner Truth after becoming a Christian and began speaking out against slavery. She also worked to improve conditions for freed slaves and women.

’s SpaceX has successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Bangabandhu-1 satellite for Bangladesh. The launch took place from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station in Florida at 2:14 p.m. ET on Thursday, and was broadcast live on SpaceX’s website.
The satellite will be placed into orbit about 33 minutes after liftoff, according to SpaceX. It is expected to arrive at its final destination around 50 minutes after launch.
Bangabandhu-1 is the first geostationary communications satellite for Bangladesh, which is located in South Asia. The satellite will provide television, telecommunications and internet services to the country.
SpaceX said it expects to land the first stage of the Falcon 9 rocket back on Earth at Landing Zone 1 (LZ-1) at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station.

, Untitled Film Still #21, 1978. Gelatin silver print, 16 x 20 in. (40.6 x 50.8 cm). The Museum of Modern Art, New York. Gift of the artist. © 2013 Cindy Sherman
Cindy Sherman is one of the most important artists working today. Her work has been exhibited widely and is included in many public collections, including MoMA’s collection. This exhibition will be the first major museum survey of her work since 1997. It will include more than 170 works from throughout her career, including early black-and-white photographs, color photographs, film stills, and video.
The exhibition will begin with a selection of Sherman’s earliest works, which she made while studying at the State University of New York at Buffalo. These works are characterized by their use of found images and objects, as well as the artist’s interest in the relationship between photography and painting

's 'Under the Gun' Documentary to Premiere at Tribeca Film Festival
Katie Couric is taking on gun violence in her new documentary, Under the Gun. The film will premiere at the 2016 Tribeca Film Festival.
The film follows Couric as she travels across the country to interview people about their views on gun control and gun violence. She also interviews victims of gun violence and families who have lost loved ones to gun violence.
"I am thrilled that our film will be premiering at the Tribeca Film Festival," Couric said in a statement. "It has been an honor to work with so many courageous survivors and families who have suffered from gun violence. I hope this film will help start a national conversation about how we can prevent these tragedies."

, J Balvin and Ozuna are the three biggest names in Latin music right now. They’re also all from Puerto Rico.
The island has been hit hard by Hurricane Maria, which made landfall on Sept. 20 as a Category 4 storm. The hurricane knocked out power to most of the island, leaving many without access to food or water.

, the 2019 Nobel Prize in Economics winner, is a pioneer in development economics. She has made significant contributions to our understanding of how to help the poorest people in developing countries escape poverty.
Duflo’s research focuses on identifying and evaluating interventions that can improve the lives of the world’s poorest people. Her work has shown that small changes in policy can have large impacts on the lives of the poor. For example, she found that providing free school meals to children in India increased their test scores by 25 percentile points.
She also showed that giving cash transfers to poor families in Mexico improved their health and nutrition. In addition, her research has demonstrated that microcredit programs can be effective in helping the poorest people in developing countries start businesses.
Duflo is the founder and director of the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL), which conducts randomized controlled trials to evaluate the effectiveness of social policies. She is

's Bugs Bunny Show
Tex Avery's Bugs Bunny Show is a 1985 animated television series produced by Hanna-Barbera Productions and based on the classic Warner Bros. cartoons of the 1940s, specifically those directed by Tex Avery. The show was originally broadcast in syndication from September 22, 1985 to August 31, 1986. It was later rerun on Cartoon Network from 1997 to 1999.
The series featured new introductions for each episode, with Bugs Bunny narrating his own adventures. The original opening sequence was replaced with a new one featuring Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck in a car driving through the desert. They stop at a gas station where they are greeted by a large rabbit who tells them that he is "the world's greatest magician". is a comedian, actor and writer. He has been nominated for 15 Primetime Emmy Awards and won two.
Chappelle was born in Washington, D.C., the son of Yvonne (née Jones), a high school teacher who worked as a nurse, and William David Chappelle III, a professor. His father is African-American and his mother is white. He grew up in Silver Spring, Maryland, where he attended Montgomery Blair High School. He graduated from Duke University with a degree in sociology.
He began performing stand-up comedy in New York City in 1986. In 1990, he made his first appearance on The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson. He also appeared on HBO's Def Comedy Jam in 1992.

Architects has unveiled designs for a new 10-storey hotel in the heart of Beijing.
The 250-room hotel will be located on the site of the former China National Aviation Corporation headquarters, which was demolished in 2013 to make way for the development.
The building is designed as a series of interlocking volumes that are stacked at different angles and heights. The top floor will feature a restaurant with views over the city, while the ground floor will house a lobby and reception area.
"The design of the hotel is inspired by the dynamic urban context of Beijing," said Zaha Hadid Architects (ZHA). "It is conceived as an ensemble of interlocking forms that create a fluid composition of spaces."
The hotel's facade will be clad in a pattern of horizontal stripes that will gradually change colour from dark grey to light grey.

Shelley was born in London on August 30, 1797. Her mother was the daughter of William Godwin, a famous political philosopher and novelist. Her father was the poet Percy Bysshe Shelley.
Mary's parents were married in 1812, but they separated in 1814. In 1816, Mary's mother died from complications after giving birth to her second child. The following year, Mary's father remarried.
In 1814, Mary began writing her first novel, Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus. It was published anonymously in 1818. She also wrote several other novels, including Valperga (1823), The Last Man (1826) and Lodore (1835).
Shelley had two children with her husband, Percy Florence Shelley. They were named Clara and Percy Florence.

on the 10 Commandments

"The Ten Commandments, they're not ten suggestions."

’s ‘Once Upon a Time in Hollywood’ Gets Release Date
Quentin Tarantino‘s Once Upon a Time in Hollywood has been given an official release date. The film, which stars Leonardo DiCaprio and Brad Pitt as two actors trying to make it in Hollywood during the Manson murders, will hit theaters on July 26, 2019.
The film is set in Los Angeles in 1969, at the height of hippie Hollywood. It follows Rick Dalton (DiCaprio), former star of a Western TV series, and his longtime stunt double Cliff Booth (Pitt) as they navigate an industry they hardly recognize anymore. Both are struggling to get work as they deal with the changing times and their own age and relevance. Meanwhile, Dalton’s next-door neighbor is Sharon Tate (Margot Robbie).
Tarantino wrote the script for the film, which he also directed. Sony Pictures Entertainment acquired distribution rights to the film in May.

, the 19-year-old gymnast who won four gold medals at the Rio Olympics, has signed a deal with World Wrestling Entertainment.

has been named the ATP World Tour Player of the Year for a record-tying fifth time.

’s “Atlas Shrugged” is a novel that has been read by millions of people. It was published in 1957 and it is still being read today. The book is about the collapse of society when the government takes over all businesses and industries. The main character, John Galt, leads a strike against the government to bring down the economy.
The book is very long and there are many characters. There are also many subplots. The book is divided into three parts. Part one is called “The Strike.” In this part, the government takes over all businesses and industries. The government forces everyone to work for them. They take away all private property. The government makes everyone pay taxes on everything they own. The government also controls what people can buy and sell. People who do not want to work for the government go on strike. This causes the economy to collapse.

's Masnavi: Book 1, The Mysteries of the Soul
Rumi's Masnavi is a collection of mystical poetry that has been translated into many languages. It is one of the most popular works in Persian literature and is considered to be one of the greatest works of Sufism. This volume contains the first book of the Masnavi, which deals with the soul and its journey through life.

, Sculpture
Constantin Brâncuși was a Romanian-born American sculptor. Born in Romania, he moved to Paris in 1904 and became part of the avant-garde community there. He was influenced by the artistic movements of Symbolism, Cubism, and Fauvism. In 1913, he began creating his distinctive style of modernist sculpture, which emphasized geometric forms. His work is characterized by simplified volumes and a reduction of form to its essentials.

has called for a day of fasting and prayer for peace in Syria on September 7.
The pope made the announcement during his weekly general audience at the Vatican on Wednesday, saying that he was inviting all Catholics to join him in praying for peace in Syria and throughout the world.
“I am asking everyone to pray the rosary every day in the month of October,” he said. “Let us ask our Mother Mary to watch over our brothers and sisters suffering because of war, violence and insecurity.”
Pope Francis also asked people to pray for peace in Iraq, where Islamic State militants have taken control of large parts of the country.
He said: “We are close to those who suffer from this situation, especially the many Christians who are victims of persecution and forced displacement.”
The pontiff’s call comes after US President Barack Obama announced plans to launch air strikes against Islamic State militants in Syria.

and Amy Poehler are hosting the Golden Globes for the second time.
The 2014 Golden Globe Awards will be hosted by Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, it has been announced.
The comedians will return to host the ceremony for a second year in a row after their successful debut last year.
"We're so excited to be back," said Fey. "It was such a fun night last year, and we can't wait to do it again."
Poehler added: "We had so much fun together last year that we just couldn't say no when they asked us back."

The duo also won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Comedy Series for their work on NBC's 30 Rock.

, the inventor of the telegraph, was born in 1791. He was a painter and an inventor who is best known for his invention of the telegraph.
Samuel Finley Breese Morse was born on April 27, 1791, in Charlestown, Massachusetts. His father was Jedidiah Morse, a Congregationalist minister and educator. As a child, Morse showed great interest in art and painting. In 1805, he began studying at Yale University, where he graduated with honors in 1810. After graduating from Yale, Morse studied painting in England and Italy. He returned to America in 1816 and became a professor of painting at the United States Military Academy at West Point.
In 1832, Morse began working on a project that would change the world: the telegraph. The telegraph was a device that sent messages over long distances using electrical signals. It was first used commercially in 18
